name: Track loader; Manufacture; At point-of-sale; 178 kW
description:
This process is part of the NETL Unit Process Library.  To access the library and the original dataset:
1) Navigate to the NETL LCA home page (http://www.netl.doe.gov/lca)
2) Then navigate to the “Unit Process Library” 
3) From the library, the unit process of interest can be found either through the "Complete Listing of the Unit Process Library link" or through the link to the "Unit Process Database" spreadsheet
4) For each process, a Data Sheet (DS) and Data File (DF) are available

BRIEF DESCRIPTION
This unit process considers amount of steel needed for the construction of one 239 HP loader to be used to haul coal at a large surface mine. The railcar was assumed to be composed of 100 percent steel plate, with a total mass of 26,373 kg.
					
GOAL AND SCOPE
The scope of this unit process covers the materials required for the construction of a single, 239 HP track loader used to scrape and push unconsolidated overburden at a large scale surface mine, as described below. The track loader is assumed to be composed entirely of steel plate. The process is based on the reference flow of 1 piece of track loader, as described below and shown in associated documentation (referenced in the Citation and Associated Documentation section below).

This unit process is used under Life Cycle (LC) Stage #1 to assist in the movement of overburden at the mine site. It is combined with other relevant equipment for LC Stage #1 in a separate construction assembly process, Coal mine equipment assembly; Production mix; Surface coal mine, Powder river basin, U.S. The assembly process quantifies the fraction of each piece of equipment needed under LC Stage #1 to produce 1 kg of coal.

BOUNDARY AND DESCRIPTION
The total weight for one empty track loader was estimated to be 26,373 kg (58,142 lbs). This figure represents manufacturer specifications for the weight of a Caterpillar model 973C track loader (Caterpillar 2008). The total weight of a track loader was readily available from published sources, but only minimal data for the material breakdown of a loader were found. Therefore, the track loader is assumed to be composed entirely of steel plate, according to the amount indicated above.

A visual representation of the boundary of this unit process is available in the associated documentation (referenced in the Citation and Associated Documentation section below). Emissions related to the physical assembly of the track loader (e.g., emitted while assembling the components of a loader, including transport of those components) are not considered in this study. Upstream emissions from the production of raw materials used for the construction of the loader (e.g., steel plate) are calculated outside of the boundary of this unit process, based on proprietary profiles available within the GaBi model. As discussed above and shown in the associated documentation (referenced below), the loader constructed in this unit process is incorporated into the assembly process for a large surface coal mine under LC Stage #1.

The associated documentation (referenced below) contains additional information regarding: relevant properties and assumptions used to calculate the amount of steel plate contained in a single track loader; modeled input and output flows; and calculation methods.

CITATION AND ASSOCIATED DOCUMENTATION
This document should be cited as: 
National Energy Technology Laboratory (NETL). 2015. NETL Life Cycle Inventory Data – Unit Process: Track loader; Manufacture; At point-of-sale; 178 kW. U.S. Department of Energy, National Energy Technology Laboratory. Last Updated: September 2015 (Version 01). Retrieved on [DATE] from [URL for this dataset].

This dataset is part of the NETL Unit Process Library.  The Library offers additional information concerning this dataset in the form of a Detailed Spreadsheet  Documentation (DS) file and a Process Documentation File (DF).  The DS file  is an Excel file that contains all of the parameters, inputs, and outputs for a given system as well as background data, calculations and quality scores.  The DF file is a PDF document that contains major assumptions and data sources that are the basis for each unit process.  The NETL Unit Process Library is located on the NETL website (netl.doe.gov) under Research / Energy Analysis / Energy Trends and Issues / Life Cycle Analysis / Unit Process Library.

This dataset was converted directly from the DS with additional supporting information provided by the DF.  Full citations for the DS and DF are given below.

DS File
National Energy Technology Laboratory (NETL). 2010. NETL Life Cycle Inventory Data – Unit Process: Track Loader, 239 Horsepower (HP), Construction. U.S. Department of Energy, National Energy Technology Laboratory. Last Updated: February 2010 (version 01). Retrieved on 6/30/2014 from: http://www.netl.doe.gov/File%20Library/Research/Energy%20Analysis/Life%20Cycle%20Analysis/UP_Library/DS_Stage1_C_Track_Loader_239_HP_2010-01.xls

DF File
National Energy Technology Laboratory (NETL). 2010. NETL Life Cycle Inventory Data – Unit Process: Track Loader, 239 Horsepower (HP), Construction. U.S. Department of Energy, National Energy Technology Laboratory. Last Updated: February 2010 (version 01). Retrieved on 6/30/2014 from: http://www.netl.doe.gov/File%20Library/Research/Energy%20Analysis/Life%20Cycle%20Analysis/UP_Library/DF_Stage1_C_Track_Loader_239_HP_2010-01.pdf

category.name: Bit. Coal and Lignite Surface Mining

processDocumentation.timeDescription: This data set is representative of best available public data from 01/01/2008 to 12/31/2008 and is not subject to limited usability within sub-time spans (e.g. summer, winter).
processDocumentation.technologyDescription: The scope of this unit process covers the materials required for the construction of a single, 239 HP track loader used to scrape and push unconsolidated overburden at a large scale surface mine, as described below. The total weight for one empty track loader was estimated to be 26,373 kg (58,142 lbs). This figure represents manufacturer specifications for the weight of a Caterpillar model 973C track loader (Caterpillar 2008). A visual representation of the boundary of this unit process is available in the associated documentation (referenced in the Citation and Associated Documentation section in the Description field).
processDocumentation.modelingConstantsDescription: All elementary and technosphere flows are calculated on a functional unit basis. Calculations involving combustion primarily to generate useful work are done using lower heating values (LHV) and calculations involving combustion primarily to generate useful heat are done using higher heating values (HHV). Unless explicitly stated in the associated reference documents applicable calculations assumed standard atmospheric temperature and pressure (SATP).

processDocumentation.intendedApplication: This is a gate-to-gate manufacturing process and can be used for any type of LCA study.
